bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wickliffe Rose, December 13, 1921

div1.p: Carter discusses the history of yellow fever in South America.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wickliffe Rose, December 13, 1921
div1.opener:
/LC
I. H. B.
History
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
December 13, 1921.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
The World's Work, with Spinden's article in it, was received
yesterday. Connor had written me in May and June of some of Mr.
Spinden's findings and I sent him excerpts of Finlay's book, being
what purported to be portions of the Chumayel MSS, as given by Bishop
Carillo y Ancona of Yucatan--both in Maya (but in Roman characters)
and in the good Bishop's translation. These stated clearly that the
epidemic of yellow fever of 1640--the first one after the arrival of
the Spaniards in 1517--was the fourth time that disease = “xekik” =
“blood-vomit”--had visited the Mayas. This epidemic was described
by Cogalludo in 1650 simply as “la peste.”

I think Mr. Spinden's findings--certainly as corroborated by
the above MSS--prove that yellow fever was in Yucatan: Campeche and
tabasco in several--at least three--epicemics prior to the Spanish
discovery of America. Even without this, the historiacal evidence
of the American origen of yellow fever was very strong--although
the biological argument indicated Africa.

In this connection, you spoke, last spring, of wishing me to
write a short history of yellow fever, presumably that within a few
years, we might write “Finis” on the last page and close the book
forever.

If you think so, I could take up this matter now--or after New
Year. The only thing I am doing that is worth while just now is ab-
stracting the articles on malaria in foreign journals and Reports
and sending them, by mimeograph, to the men engaged in that work in
the U. S. Sometimes there is a good deal of this, but I judge I
could find time for the yellow fever. The only trouble I foresee is
that I can't lay my hands on the notes I made in 1916 on the early
Brazilian epidemics and will have some trouble in getting data on
this country. Yellow fever seems to have been introduced three times
into Bahia and died out twice. The third time, the city being larger
and with more immigration, it was permanent.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
